0.20.text: Not everybody knows about stocks and shares

3.74.text: and how the pound is doing, and things like these

6.44.text: because we live in the real world.

8.18.text: I don't really watch the news

13.46.text: There's a lot of people like that I think.

15.02.text:
What about the FTSE 100, 
do you understand that?

17.02.text: I've never heard of it in my life

17.72.text: I don't know what that is

19.06.text:
I don't know what that is.
What is that?

21.72.text: Most of it is totally confusing

23.10.text:
I just wish they'd speak proper English
so we could understand, do you know what I mean?

30.32.text: People just had to go with their gut feel.

32.12.text: It didn't really make any sense

36.22.text: they weren't really offering any truthful information.

40.16.text:
When you don't understand
what they're trying to tell you

43.12.text: and it's going over your head

44.98.text:
and they're bullying you into 
what their beliefs are

48.50.text: We're supposed to be a democratic country

50.44.text: so we have the right to make our own minds up.

54.10.text: So if you look at a lot of the headlines today

56.14.text:
using a lot of jargon saying things
  like the FTSE is falling

59.84.text: and the value of the pound is really low

62.08.text: And the Bank of England is doing this and that

64.24.text: How do you think people feel about that jargon?

65.98.text: Do you think they can follow those arguments?

68.70.text: If they had, they wouldn't have voted Leave

76.00.text: you know, just trying to frighten people

77.68.text: and I think, to be honest,

80.60.text: Well I guess they need to

87.88.text: Do you remember they started a scheme years ago on Plain English?

91.50.text: I wonder if maybe we could have something like that

97.34.text: I think it would be great if

99.34.text: if it was explained in easier terms

101.34.text: and we had that plain-speaking concept.
